_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:

Cargill is committed to providing the necessary resources to ensure the safe handling of Epichlorohydrin to prevent accident releases of Epichlorohydrin by having appropriate safeguards (process safety information, process hazardous analysis, operating procedures, management of change, hot work procedures, mechanical integrity program, employee training, etc.) in place.  In the event of an emergency, Cargill is committed to providing the resources necessary to report, contain and cleanup accidental releases of Epichlorohydrin in a manner that minimizes the adverse impacts to its on-site personnel as well as to the surrounding community / environment.



Facility Description and Regulated Substances Handled:

Cargill acquired the Polystar LLC Dalton, GA facility in February 2014 and the facility uses Epichlorohydrin to produce numerous epoxy additives.  Cargill receives Epichlorohydrin via tanker trucks and stores up to 156,800 lbs of Epichlorohydrin in an above ground storage tank.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:

Cargill has developed its Epichlorohydrin chemical release prevention program based upon the requirements of USEPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) and OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations.



Five Year Accident History:

During the past five years, no accidents involving the accidental release of epichlorohydrin have resulted in any on-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage or any known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.



Emergency Response Program:

Cargill trains its employees initially (and annually thereafter) on its Emergency Action Plan and how to recognize / report emergencies to the appropriate facility personnel and government agencies. Emergency response activities have also been coordinated with the Dalton Fire Department and Whit

field County LEPC.  Additionally, Cargill has retained a Hazmat emergency response organization (Clean Harbors) to provide emergency hazmat spill containment and remediation services.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

Since taking ownership of the Dalton, GA Polystar LLC facility in February 2014, Cargill recently conducted its second Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the epichlorohydrin process in August-2021) and is awaiting the final PHA report.  Any corrective actions identified by the PHA will be resolved in a timely manner.
